result.text:
ELON: PHOTONS ARE ALL YOU NEED TO TRAIN THE AI

‚ÄúThe really wild thing about [Tesla‚Äôs] end-to-end training is that it learns to read, like it can read signs, but we never taught it to read. 

We never taught it what a car was or what a person was or a cyclist. 

It learned what all those things are, what all the objects are on the road from video, just from watching videos. 

Just like humans. 

I mean humans are photons in, controls out. 

The vast majority of information reaching our brain is from our eyes. 

The output is our motor signals to our fingers and mouth in order to communicate. 

Photons in, controls out.‚Äù

Source: Interview with Lex Fridman, November 2023

In essence:

items.message: Isn‚Äôt this just the energy * time variant of Heisenberg‚Äôs uncertainty principle?

The energy cost described in the study does indeed connect to the energy-time uncertainty principle (often written as ŒîE Œît ‚â• ƒß/2), which sets fundamental limits on how precisely you can measure time without introducing energy uncertainty‚Äîor vice versa‚Äîin quantum systems. However, the paper goes beyond a direct restatement of that principle by experimentally quantifying the entropic (and thus energetic) overhead of extracting classical information from a quantum clock setup, showing it's orders of magnitude higher than theoretical minima in practice.

In essence:
- The uncertainty principle provides a lower bound on the trade-off, implying that precise timing measurements inherently require energy input to resolve ambiguities in the system's state.
- This particular experiment (using electron tunneling in a double quantum dot) demonstrates that the real-world process of "reading" the clock‚Äîconverting quantum superposition into classical bits‚Äîgenerates massive entropy through irreversible measurement, leading to heat dissipation up to a billion times the clock's operational energy.





 This entropy surge isn't just a theoretical bound but a practical bottleneck, potentially linking to broader ideas like the thermodynamic arrow of time.

Earlier theoretical work has explored similar time-energy costs in quantum measurements, framing them as extensions of uncertainty relations.



 So while it's not *solely* the uncertainty principle rebranded, the findings build directly on it, highlighting implications for quantum computing where measurement efficiency could limit scalability without innovations in low-entropy readout techniques.

legacy.description: Deeply researched product, growth, and career advice

result.text:
Top takeaways from my chat with @thisisgrantlee:

1. The first 30 seconds of using your product should be so good it earns the next 30 seconds. When Gamma wasn‚Äôt growing, they stopped everything and spent three months perfecting just the first 30 seconds of using their product. They made it so compelling that new users would immediately tell their friends. This single change transformed their growth trajectory.

2. Focus on one simple promise, not many features. Think of it like throwing eggs to someone: they can catch one, but if you throw five at once, they‚Äôll drop them all. Your users are selfish, vain, and lazy‚Äîyou have 30 seconds to show value before they leave. Gamma focused on ‚Äúcreate a slide in seconds‚Äù rather than listing 10 features.

3. Don‚Äôt spend on ads until over half your growth comes from word of mouth. If you try to buy growth before your product spreads organically, you‚Äôre wasting money filling a leaky bucket. Gamma didn‚Äôt invest heavily in advertising until more than 50% of new users came from people sharing organically.

4. Work with hundreds of small creators instead of a few big influencers. Rather than blowing your budget on five or six well-known influencers who treat it like just another ad read, find thousands of micro-influencers whose audiences genuinely care about tools like yours. Teachers sharing with teachers, consultants with consultants‚Äîthese tight communities create authentic word of mouth that spreads fast.

5. Spend time personally onboarding each early creator like they‚Äôre joining your team. Don‚Äôt just send influencers a script. Jump on calls, walk them through the product, help them understand what makes it special, and let them tell your story in their own voice. This investment turns them into genuine advocates who post about you repeatedly instead of treating it like any other sponsorship.

6. Hire painfully slowly and only exceptional people. Gamma serves 50 million users with just 50 people and makes a profit. All 10 original employees are still there five years later. They never set headcount goals because that makes you hire to hit a number instead of hiring only when you find someone exceptional. When someone is exceptional, give them more responsibility, not less‚Äîtop performers want harder challenges.

7. Test prototypes with 20 people on UserTesting before investing in a big project. Use platforms like Voicepanel or UserTesting to watch real people try your prototype. They‚Äôll show you problems you never see because you‚Äôre too close to your product. Gamma goes from idea to results in a single day‚Äîmorning idea, afternoon testing, evening results. This saves months of building things nobody wants.

8. Choose problems you‚Äôll care about for 10 years. Before worrying about technology or tactics, ask if this problem matters enough to you personally that you‚Äôd dedicate a decade to solving it. Founders who are missionaries rather than mercenaries build better products because their authentic commitment shows through to customers and attracts people who want to build alongside you for the long term.

result.text:
When people talk about why Indian Americans seem to do better overall than Chinese Americans, the debate online often gets lost in ideas about ‚Äúculture‚Äù or ‚Äúnational character.‚Äù But if you go back to history and look at how the U.S. immigration system actually works, the explanation is quite straightforward: the success of Indian Americans today is mainly the result of the 1965 U.S. immigration reform.

The 1965 Immigration and Nationality Act is where everything starts. Before that, the U.S. basically welcomed only white European immigrants. Asians were very few and faced strict limits. After 1965, the U.S. began prioritizing high education and professional skills for immigration. For the first time, America opened its doors to skilled talent from around the world.

For India, this change was huge. Before 1965, there were only about ten thousand Indian immigrants in the whole country. After the reform, large numbers of highly educated doctors, engineers, and scholars came to the U.S. They became the foundation of the Indian American community, and their background shaped the group‚Äôs overall education and income levels.

On the other hand, bc of The Cultural Revolution, the wave of highly educated, highly skilled Chinese immigrants didn‚Äôt really start until the late ‚Äô80s and early ‚Äô90s, and it didn‚Äôt reach its peak until the 2000s. Before that, the Chinese immigrant population was very mixed in background, came through many different pathways: early Chinese Americans born in the U.S., refugees from Southeast Asia, highly educated migrants from Taiwan, and later students and economic migrants from mainland China. This created a very diverse group with big differences in class and background. Chinese Americans were never a single ‚Äúfiltered‚Äù elite group, but a mix of many historical and political waves.

Because of this, Chinese Americans show a ‚Äúhigh peak + long tail‚Äù pattern: many highly educated professionals, but also many who arrived as refugees or working-class migrants. This isn‚Äôt about ability, it‚Äôs a result of different immigration routes.

Put simply, the differences we see today come from when and how each group came to the U.S., not from culture or ‚Äútalent‚Äù, despite many people believe.
